action.action-desc: Mr. Sessions (for himself, Mr. Meeks, Mr. Young of Indiana, and Mr. Johnson of Ohio) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Energy and Commerce, and in addition to the Committee on Ways and Means, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned

form.official-title: To amend title XVIII of the Social Security Act to require reporting of certain data by providers and suppliers of air ambulance services for purposes of reforming reimbursements for such services under the Medicare program, and for other purposes.

paragraph.text: Air medical critical care transport is an essential component of the healthcare system.
The presence of air medical services in rural areas provides tens of millions of rural Americans with access to critical care within an hour of injury.
As an emergency responder, air medical providers must maintain readiness 24 hours a day and 7 days a week.
Air medical providers transport all emergent patients for which they are dispatched regardless of insurance status or ability to pay.

The air ambulance fee schedule under the Medicare program was first implemented in 2002 and developed through negotiated rulemaking, which required the new fee schedule to be created in a budget neutral manner. As such, the Medicare air ambulance fee schedule has never reflected true costs.
Since the implementation of the air ambulance fee schedule under the Medicare program, reimbursements have only been adjusted by inflationary updates averaging 2.2 percent a year.
Operational readiness and safety enhancement costs have grown at a far faster rate than the Medicare inflationary updates, creating a fundamental imbalance within the air ambulance fee schedule.
It is imperative that balance be restored to the air ambulance fee schedule to preserve access to timely care for tens of millions of Americans.

section.text: Section 1834(l) of the Social Security Act (42 U.S.C. 1395m(l)) is amended—

paragraph.text: in paragraph (3)(B), by striking subparagraph (C) and inserting subparagraph (C) and paragraph (16); and
by adding at the end the following new paragraphs:

subparagraph.header: Reduction in update for failure to report

clause.text: With respect to air ambulance services furnished by a supplier or provider of air ambulance services during 2017 or any subsequent year, in the case the supplier or provider does not submit data to the Secretary in accordance with subparagraph (C) with respect to such year, after determining the percentage increase under paragraph (3)(B), and after application of paragraph (3)(C), the Secretary shall reduce such percentage increase for payments under the fee schedule under this subsection during such year by 2.0 percentage points.

The application of this subparagraph may result in such percentage increase being less than 0.0 for a year, and may result in payment rates under the fee schedule under this subsection for a year being less than such payment rates for the preceding year.

subparagraph.text: Any reduction under subparagraph (A) shall apply only with respect to the year involved and the Secretary shall not take into account such reduction in computing the payment amount under the fee schedule under this subsection for a subsequent year.

For 2017 and each subsequent year, for purposes of this paragraph, each supplier or provider of air ambulance services shall submit to the Secretary data specified under subparagraph (D) for the reporting period (specified by the Secretary) for the year. Such data shall be submitted in a form and manner, and at a time, specified by the Secretary for purposes of this subparagraph.
For purposes of reporting data for air ambulance services furnished during a year, the data described in this subparagraph are cost data on the following:

clause.text: Recurring training relating to aviation, maintenance, communication, and clinical.
Hull and aviation liability insurance, life insurance, and professional malpractice insurance.

subparagraph.text: Not later than January 1, 2018, the Secretary shall select no less than two quality measures with respect to which providers and suppliers of air ambulance services may voluntarily submit to the Secretary data. In selecting such measures, the Secretary shall consider the following:

clause.text: Ventilator use in patients with advanced airways.
Blood glucose check for altered mental status.
DASH 1A-definitive airway sans hypoxia/hypotension on first attempt.
Not later than July 1, 2019, subject to clause (iii), the Secretary shall submit to Congress a report on the data described in subparagraph (E) submitted to the Secretary.

Not later than July 1, 2019, subject to clause (iii), the Comptroller General of the United States shall submit to Congress a report on the data described in subparagraph (D) and subparagraph (E) submitted under this paragraph. Such report shall include a recommendation on the adequate amount of reimbursement under this title to providers and suppliers of air ambulance services for furnishing such services that would reflect operational costs of such providers and suppliers and preserve access to critical air medical services and such other recommendations as the Comptroller General deems appropriate.
The reports submitted under subclauses (i) and (ii) shall not include any information that the Secretary or Comptroller General, respectively, determines is proprietary.
